en: Interview with Helen Barnett, 2020-08-14

Interview with Helen Barnett, resident of Sevier County, conducted by Jennifer Benedetto Beals. Barnett discusses the aid provided by her church, the Great Smoky Mountains Church of Christ. The efforts grew from providing water and food to survivors to assisting with bills and large items as people were rebuilding. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Well the emotional changes with people is just taking time. That's why we try to step in as much as we did the financial. They didn't have to worry about that. They could take more care of their selves, their emotional stability."

Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Helen Barnett, 2020-08-14
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and share your reason for participating in this project?
How long have you lived in Sevierville? What is your life like there?
What were the days like leading up to the fires?
When did you realize that it wasn't just smoke, but a fire sweeping through Gatlinburg?
Did you go to the church the next morning to help victims of the fire? What did you do there?
What were the people coming to you for help like? What were their experiences, or how were they reacting?
Did you realize right away how many homes had been lost?
How many people reached out to the church for help?
How long was the church providing support and how did it change over time?
Have you kept in touch with any of the families or individuals?
Did you hear back from any of the people you helped?
Prior to the fires, had the church provided any relief efforts?
How would you assess the recovery efforts in Gatlinburg?
What was similar or different between your experiences helping after Katrina and these wildfires?
How do you feel this impacted the community and your church long-term?
How did this impact you emotionally?
Were there any changes in the community afterwards?
Do you know of any people that left after the fires?
Have you seen any new members in your church? Has the church done any more relief efforts?
Have you thought about what you might do if something similar happens?
Was there anything good or surprising that came out of this tragedy?
Is there anything else that you can tell us about the experience? Is there anything you wish would have gone differently?
How did you mobilize in the very beginning? Were church members already in communications to meet the next day?
How did you mobilize in the very beginning? Were church members already in communications to meet the next day?
When did you realize how large of an impact this would have on the community?
Is there anything that we haven't covered that you would like to share? Would you do the same thing if this happened again?
Do you think people had a hard time accepting the help? So you were actively reaching out to people instead of just waiting fot them to ask?
Did you have people seeking temporary shelter because they didn't realize they had lost everything?
Are you planning on staying in Sevierville?
